steps.title: Start by making a small change in your daily life.
steps.content: Start by making a small change in your daily life. You don’t have to turn your whole life around all at once. Instead, pick something small that you can work toward today. A few small decisions are just as good as one large decision. [1] X Expert Source Tracey Rogers, MA Certified Life Coach Expert Interview. 6 January 2020. Good changes might include commuting by walking or biking, cutting back on alcohol or cigarettes, getting up earlier, going to bed earlier, reducing time on the internet or a device, scheduling time for yourself, or trying a new recipe each week.

steps.title: Practice positive self-talk.
steps.content: Practice positive self-talk. Catch negative or self-critical thoughts as they pass through your head. Acknowledge that those thoughts exist as an emotional signal, then picture the negative thoughts like clouds drifting by and let them go. If you find yourself using a lot of “should,” “must,” “always” or “never” statements, that’s a good sign to ask yourself, “Am I speaking to myself the way I’d speak to a friend?” [2] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source For instance, instead of saying, “I should’ve prepared more for that presentation,” give yourself credit for what you did do. For example, “I did the best that I could given the tight deadline, and my coworkers told me it was helpful.” Turn statements expressing worries into hopeful statements. You could turn a thought like, “I’m so nervous for this test” into a statement like, “This test is going to be tough, but I’m going to do my best.”

steps.title: Set short-term and long-term goals.
steps.content: Set short-term and long-term goals. If you have any areas of your life that you want to change, try breaking them down into goals you can work toward. Create short-term goals that you can reach in a few months as well as long-term goals that might take a few years. [3] X Trustworthy Source American Psychological Association Leading scientific and professional organization of licensed psychologists Go to source Short-term goals include: quitting smoking, walking for 30 minutes per day, connecting with friends and family once a week, reading 1 book a month, and setting aside 2 hours per week for art and creativity. Long-term goals include: saving money for a deposit on a house, building your resumé to apply for a new job, having children within the next 5 years, and saving enough money to go back to school.

steps.title: Set aside time for your passions.
steps.content: Set aside time for your passions. Pursuing your hobbies and interests can bring you closer to yourself and build your self-confidence. Reconnect with an old hobby you used to enjoy, or take a chance and try something new. [4] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Create a list of things you’ve always wanted to try, whether it’s going to the new cafe that opened downtown or learning how to speak Italian. Take a step to cross 1 item off your list every day.

steps.title: Take responsibility for your own actions.
steps.content: Take responsibility for your own actions. Instead of blaming other people or circumstances for your lack of achievements, try to take ownership over them. That way, you can feel like you have control over your own life instead of leaving it up to others. It can be tough to do this at first, but it will be helpful in the long run. [5] X Research source For example, instead of saying “I don’t have time to work toward my goals,” you could say, “I’m not making enough time throughout the week to work toward my goals.” If you find yourself saying “I can’t” a lot, replace it with “I don’t want to.” This can help show you that you have authority over your own life.

steps.title: Accept your mistakes or setbacks.
steps.content: Accept your mistakes or setbacks. You won’t be able to achieve all of your goals perfectly, and that’s okay! Remember that you’re only human, and learn to forgive yourself if you mess up. [6] X Research source The more you accept yourself for who you are, the more others will, too. Remember that you should only compare yourself against who you were in the past, not against anyone else.

steps.title: Connect with your friends and family members.
steps.content: Connect with your friends and family members. Call close friends or family, arrange for dinner with a friend or go meet some new people at a community event. Social interaction is a basic need, and it can improve your mood as well as boost your self-esteem. [7] X Trustworthy Source American Psychological Association Leading scientific and professional organization of licensed psychologists Go to source If meeting new people is difficult, start small. Look for a local community event in your local paper or have a video chat with a close friend in another location. Try to schedule something at the same time every week so it becomes a regular part of your life.

steps.title: Network with people in your field.
steps.content: Network with people in your field. Talking to others who are working toward your same goals can only help you on your journey. Try to surround yourself with like-minded people by attending conferences, making friends at work, or joining a club. [8] X Research source It’s important to have a support system. If you need help or advice, you can approach someone that you’ve networked with since they’re in the same field as you.

steps.title: Say “no” if you don’t want to do something.
steps.content: Say “no” if you don’t want to do something. If you tend to avoid conflict, saying “no” to someone can be tough. However, you should try to push your own boundaries and avoid taking on too much at one time. Give yourself a few moments to process the request, then politely decline. [9] X Research source You could say something like, “Unfortunately, that doesn’t work for me.” Or, “No, I’m unavailable.”

steps.title: Make decisions and stick to them.
steps.content: Make decisions and stick to them. Waffling back and forth can make you feel like your opinions don’t matter (but they do!). Try to stick to your guns, even on small decisions, like what movie to watch or where to go for dinner. [10] X Research source This is especially important when your decisions involve other people. You can take their opinions into account, but don’t let them sway you every time!

steps.title: Speak up for yourself.
steps.content: Speak up for yourself. If you have an opinion or a need, state it clearly. You can do this with your friends, your romantic partner, your family members, and your co-workers. If you don’t speak up, they’ll never know what you need! [11] X Research source Say something like, “Hey, I felt kind of sad when you didn’t invite me to that party. In the future, could you just shoot me a quick text to see if I’m available?” Or, “I need you to let me know in advance when you’re having company over so I can prepare myself.”

steps.title: Get into an exercise routine.
steps.content: Get into an exercise routine. Exercising is not only good for your physical health, it’s good for your mental health, too. You don’t have to jump into an intense workout right away; start slowly by going for walks, taking a hike, or riding bicycles with friends. [12] X Research source If you have a dog, try to take them out for a walk once a day. This will get you both out of the house and into a good exercise routine.

steps.title: Maintain a balanced diet and stay hydrated.
steps.content: Maintain a balanced diet and stay hydrated. An unhealthy diet and not enough water can make you feel grumpy or irritable. Try to eat 3 balanced meals per day and try to drink around 8 glasses of water to keep your body healthy. [13] X Trustworthy Source HelpGuide Nonprofit organization dedicated to providing free, evidence-based mental health and wellness resources. Go to source Nuts, avocados, flaxseed, beans, leafy greens, and fresh fruit are all great brain food. Caffeine, alcohol, trans fats, sugary snacks, and fried food can all negatively impact your mood. It’s okay to have things like this occasionally, but try not to have them every day.

steps.title: Sleep for at least 8 hours every night.
steps.content: Sleep for at least 8 hours every night. If you don’t get enough sleep, you might feel fatigued, moody, or irritable throughout the day. Try to go to bed around the same time every night, and work toward getting 7 to 8 hours of sleep. [14] X Trustworthy Source HelpGuide Nonprofit organization dedicated to providing free, evidence-based mental health and wellness resources. Go to source A consistent sleep schedule will help you regulate your mood and leave you feeling refreshed and ready to tackle each day.

steps.title: Practice meditation.
steps.content: Practice meditation. Meditation helps to focus your mind and ground your thoughts and feelings. If you can, sit down and meditate once a day to become more aware about your body and your mind. [15] X Research source Doing meditation on your own can be tough at first. Look up some guided meditation videos on YouTube to walk you through the process when you first start.

steps.title: Volunteer to give back to your community.
steps.content: Volunteer to give back to your community. See if your local homeless shelter or food bank needs help on the weekends or after work. Giving back to others can help raise your self-esteem and help give your life purpose. [16] X Trustworthy Source American Psychological Association Leading scientific and professional organization of licensed psychologists Go to source It can also help you make new connections and befriend people who are a positive influence on your life.
